descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to some major works by Charles Dickens, who is arguably England's second greatest writer next to Shakespeare. He came of age as a writer while mass media was being created, and he made use of those communication tools to gain enormous popularity and influence. Some have even called him the world's first literary celebrity. The course examines three novels in the context of Victorian society-its values, tensions, and problems-and the complex relationship between the author and his audience, whom Dickens aimed both to please and to chastise. We will also look at some of Dickens's short essays, published in journals that he edited, which help explain the range of his interests. Texts include the novels Bleak House, Hard Times, and Our Mutual Friend.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Students who enroll should have fulfilled the SPS writing requirement or taken equivalent writing courses. Previous literature course strongly recommended.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
To recognize the defining attributes of Dickens's fiction, both in term of style and content -What makes Dickens distinctive

To articulate Dickens's agenda as a writer by analyzing his use of characters, themes, and structures-What Dickens is trying to accomplish

To explain the relationship between Dickens's literature and Victorian society, focusing especially on the relationship between the author and his readers-How to understand the relation between the author and his society

To develop proficiency in writing literary analyses that employ textual evidence and, where appropriate, external research, to advance an argument-How to illuminate the complexity of the literature through analytic writing.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The class will be primarily discussion-based, though short lectures will be provided to give relevant background information. We will often begin each session with a small-group activity to focus our thoughts and stimulate discussion.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on class participation and attendance (10%), two short 5-page papers (25% each), and an 8-page paper (40%) that will utilize focused research to add greater depth to the treatment of the topic.
